content: The "College Student Relief Act of 2007" may be cited as the Act. It includes interest rate reductions for college students. The College Student Relief Act of 2007, also known as the Act, introduces reduced interest rates for undergraduate subsidized loans disbursed between July 1, 2006, and January 1, 2012. The interest rate for loans disbursed between July 1, 2006, and July 1, 2007, is set at 6.80 percent. The interest rates for undergraduate subsidized loans disbursed between July 1, 2007, and July 1, 2010, are as follows: 6.12 percent for loans disbursed between July 1, 2007, and July 1, 2008, 5.44 percent for loans disbursed between July 1, 2008, and July 1, 2009, 4.76 percent for loans disbursed between July 1, 2009, and July 1, 2010. The interest rates for undergraduate subsidized loans are specified based on the disbursement dates. For loans disbursed between July 1, 2010, and July 1, 2011, the rate is 4.08 percent, and for loans disbursed between July 1, 2011, and January 1, 2012, the rate is 3.40 percent. Amendments are made to the Special allowance cross reference and Direct Loan Interest Rates sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965. For Federal Direct Stafford Loans to undergraduate students, the interest rates vary based on disbursement dates. Between July 1, 2006, and January 1, 2012, rates ranged from 6.80% to 6.12% depending on the disbursement year. For loans disbursed between July 1, 2008, and July 1, 2011, interest rates ranged from 5.44% to 4.08% based on the disbursement year. The interest rate for loans disbursed between July 1, 2011, and January 1, 2012, is 3.40% on the unpaid principal balance. SEC. 3. REDUCTION OF LENDER INSURANCE PERCENTAGE. Amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965 insures 95 percent of unpaid principal of loans, with exceptions for certain types of loans. Effective date for the amendment is July 1, 2007. SEC. 4. GUARANTEE AGENCY COLLECTION RETENTION. Section 428(c)(6)(A)(ii) of the Higher Education Act is amended to adjust the percentage of payments for use in accordance with section 422B over specific time periods. The Higher Education Act is amended to adjust payment percentages over specific time periods, with changes in percentages from 2008 to 2010 and beyond based on regulations. SEC. 5 eliminates exceptional performer status for lenders by amending the Higher Education Act of 1965. This includes removing section 428I and making conforming amendments to other sections. The effective date for these changes is July 1, 2007. SEC. 6 involves the reduction of lender special allowance payments. Section 438(b)(2)(I) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to reduce special allowance payments for loans disbursed on or after July 1, 2007. The amendment includes changing the interest rate percentage from 2.34 percent to 2.24 percent. The amendment reduces special allowance payments for loans disbursed after July 1, 2007 by adjusting interest rate percentages. Smaller lenders are exempt from certain calculations based on Secretary designation. When determining eligibility for exemption under clause (vii) for holders of eligible loans, the Secretary ranks holders by total principal amount, calculates the total amount held, and identifies consecutively ranked holders. When determining eligibility for exemption under clause (vii) for holders of eligible loans, the Secretary ranks holders by total principal amount and identifies consecutively ranked holders, designating small lenders based on specific criteria. SEC. 7 amends loan fees under the Higher Education Act of 1965, specifying the amount to be deducted from borrowers. The fee is 0.50 percent for loans disbursed between October 1, 1993, and July 1, 2007, and 1.0 percent for loans disbursed after July 1, 2007. SEC. 8 introduces an interest payment rebate fee. SEC. 8 introduces an interest payment rebate fee for consolidation loans based on applications received on or after July 1, 2007. If 90 percent or more of the total principal and accrued unpaid interest outstanding on the loans held by any holder is comprised of consolidation loans, the rebate for the holder will be 1.30 percent of the principal plus accrued unpaid interest on such loans. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
